Introduction

Nephrotic syndrome is defined by heavy proteinuria (>3.5 g/day), hypoalbuminemia, and peripheral edema.  It results from increased permeability of the glomerular filtration barrier (

figure 1
), which is composed of capillary endothelial cells, the glomerular basement membrane (GBM), and specialized epithelial cells called podocytes.  The underlying injury in nephrotic syndrome is noninflammatory and involves podocytes and the GBM without significant involvement of other glomerular structures; this is in contrast to the diffuse inflammatory damage seen in nephritic syndrome (discussed in a separate article).

Pathophysiology



In nephrotic syndrome, glomerular injury primarily affects the podocytes and is isolated from the inflammatory mediators in the circulation (Bowman space); therefore, it is noninflammatory.  Podocytes play a crucial role in maintaining the selectivity of the glomerular filtration barrier, and their dysfunction allows proteins that are normally retained in the blood to pass through, resulting in significant proteinuria.



The consequent hypoalbuminemia decreases plasma oncotic pressure, causing fluid to leak into the interstitial space; this initiates edema formation.  Transient volume depletion activates the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), increasing sodium retention and exacerbating edema (underfilling mechanism; secondary sodium retention).  Additionally, primary defects in renal sodium handling (eg, aberrant filtration of plasma proteases that activate epithelial sodium channels) contribute to edema independent of decreased oncotic pressure (overfilling mechanism; primary sodium retention) (

figure 2
).



Additional complications of urinary protein losses include:



  • Hyperlipidemia:  Hypoalbuminemia stimulates hepatic synthesis of lipoproteins and decreases LDL clearance (increased synthesis of proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 [PCSK9]).  Lipiduria may also be present.
  • Hypercoagulability:  Loss of anticoagulant proteins (eg, antithrombin III) and increased synthesis of procoagulant factors predispose to thromboembolism, particularly renal vein thrombosis (possibly due to the hemoconcentration [ie, higher viscosity] of the postglomerular circulation).
  • Infection risk:  Loss of immunoglobulins and opsonizing factors increase the risk of infections, especially those caused by encapsulated bacteria.
  • Protein malnutrition and, in severe cases, intravascular volume depletion from very low serum albumin.

Etiologies



Nephrotic syndrome can be caused by systemic diseases (~30%) or renally-limited conditions (~70%).

Systemic diseases



  • Diabetes mellitus:  Chronic hyperglycemia leads to glomerular hyperfiltration, with glomerulosclerosis and progressive kidney damage.
  • Amyloidosis:  Deposition of amyloid proteins within the glomeruli, tubules, and interstitium causes nephrotic syndrome with renal insufficiency.  This can occur in primary (AL) or secondary (AA) amyloidosis.
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) (class V lupus nephritis):  resembles primary membranous nephropathy (discussed below) and can occur without other signs or symptoms of SLE.

Renally-limited conditions



  • Minimal change disease (MCD) usually presents with an abrupt onset of nephrotic syndrome and accounts for 10%-15% of cases in adults (70%-90% in children).

    • Primary (most common):  T-cell-mediated circulating permeability factors (eg, IL-13) alter podocyte function, often following an upper respiratory tract infection.
    • Secondary:  associated with medications (eg, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, antibiotics), bacterial infections, and allergies.
  • Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is more insidious and more common than MCD.  It can sometimes cause mild microscopic hematuria without dysmorphic red blood cells or casts.  An advanced form known as collapsing glomerulopathy (CG) can be seen in HIV and is associated with APOL1 polymorphisms.
    • Primary:  Circulating permeability factors (eg, suPAR) lead to podocyte injury and dysfunction.
    • Secondary (most common):  podocyte injury from glomerular hyperfiltration (eg, severe obesity, solitary kidney), toxins (eg, heroin), or infection (eg, HIV).  May present with subnephrotic proteinuria and normal serum albumin.
  • Membranous nephropathy (MN) is characterized by immune complex deposition along the GBM with podocyte dysfunction, presenting with gradual proteinuria.  It has the strongest association with venous thromboembolism.
    • Primary (most common):  Autoantibodies target podocyte antigens (eg, PLA2R, THSD7A) with complement activation.
    • Secondary:  caused by infections (eg, hepatitis B, syphilis), medications (eg, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, gold, penicillamine), malignancy (particularly solid tumors), and SLE (class V lupus nephritis).


MCD and FSGS/CG can be classified as podocytopathies because histologic findings include varying degrees of podocyte effacement.  MN is not included in this classification because the podocyte effacement is variable and less prominent; instead, prominent immune deposits within the GBM are seen.  Specific histologic findings are discussed later.

Evaluation



The diagnostic evaluation of nephrotic syndrome involves a combination of clinical assessment, laboratory tests, and histopathologic examination of kidney tissue.  Key components include:



  • Urinalysis and quantification of proteinuria:  Dipstick urinalysis typically reveals 3+ or 4+ proteinuria, with a spot urine protein-to-creatinine ratio >3.5 g/g, indicating nephrotic-range proteinuria.  The value obtained on spot urine protein-to-creatinine ratio corresponds with the value obtained on 24-hour urine protein collection; spot value measurements have largely replaced 24-hour urine collection.  Significant hematuria or red blood cell casts should raise suspicion for an alternative diagnosis or coexisting nephritic syndrome.
  • Serum albumin and lipid panel:  Hypoalbuminemia (<3.5 g/dL) and hyperlipidemia are characteristic.
  • Serum creatinine:  obtained to assess kidney function, which is preserved in most cases of nephrotic syndrome but may be elevated in severe cases (eg, collapsing FSGS).
  • Serologic tests:  ordered to assess for systemic disease, such as hemoglobin A1c (diabetes mellitus), serum/urine protein electrophoresis and free light chain assay (amyloidosis), and antinuclear/anti-dsDNA antibodies (SLE).  Serologic testing for renally-limited etiologies of nephrotic syndrome is largely limited to anti-PLA2R antibody measurement (primary membranous nephropathy).
  • Kidney biopsy:  required in most cases that are not easily attributable to systemic disease or in cases in which anti-PLA2R antibody testing is not diagnostic.

Renal biopsy and pathology



Kidney biopsy with histologic analysis via light microscopy (LM), electronic microscopy (EM), and immunofluorescence (IF) typically provides the underlying diagnosis.  Diabetic nephropathy usually presents with classic LM findings of diffuse glomerular scarring (sometimes nodular), GBM thickening, and arteriolar hyalinosis with thickening.  The key histologic findings for renally-limited causes of nephrotic syndrome include:



  • MCD

    • LM:  normal-appearing glomeruli
    • EM:  diffuse foot process effacement (
      image 1
      )
    • IF:  no immune deposits
  • FSGS
    • LM:  segmental scarring involving less than 50% of glomeruli (
      image 2
      )
    • EM:  diffuse foot process effacement.  Possible electron-dense deposits in sclerotic areas
    • IF:  no immune deposits
  • CG (collapsing variant of FSGS)
    • LM:  scarring and collapse of entire glomerular tuft with obliteration of capillary lumens.  Hyperplasia and hypertrophy of overlying podocytes, forming pseudocrescents.  Tubulointerstitial damage, including tubular atrophy, interstitial fibrosis, and inflammation.
    • EM/IF:  similar to FSGS.
  • Membranous nephropathy
    • LM:  diffuse GBM thickening with spikes on special silver stain.
    • EM:  subepithelial, electron-dense deposits along GBM.  Foot process effacement (
      image 3
      ).
    • IF:  diffuse, granular IgG and C3 immune deposits along capillary loops (
      image 4
      ).

Management



In nephrotic syndrome, general therapeutic measures include:



  • RAAS blockade:  ACE inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers are first-line agents for reducing proteinuria and slowing the progression of kidney disease.
  • Sodium restriction and diuretics:  Salt intake should be limited to 2 g/day; loop diuretics (eg, furosemide) are first-line to manage edema but do not delay progression of kidney disease.  Thiazides may be needed when loop diuretics alone are not sufficient.
  • Statins:  used to treat hyperlipidemia and reduce the risk of cardiovascular complications.
  • Prophylactic anticoagulation:  considered in patients with severe nephrotic syndrome from any etiology (serum albumin <2.0 g/dL) or membranous nephropathy with risk factors.
  • Pneumococcal vaccine:  provided to all patients with nephrotic syndrome due to increased risk of infection by encapsulated bacteria.


Nephrotic syndrome due to systemic disease is treated by managing the underlying disease (eg, antihyperglycemic medications in diabetes).  Specific treatment of renally-limited nephrotic syndrome is dependent on the disease entity, whether it is primary or secondary, and disease severity.



Podocytopathies (eg, MCD, FSGS/CG) that are primary in etiology involve immune-mediated circulating factors and are therefore typically responsive to corticosteroids (particularly MCD); steroid-sparing agents (eg, mycophenolate, cyclosporine, rituximab) are sometimes used in patients who are intolerant of corticosteroids or who have resistant disease or frequent relapse, or in severe cases.  Given its advanced stage, CG is often resistant to treatment.  Secondary podocytopathies require addressing the underlying cause, such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug cessation in MCD, weight loss in obesity-related FSGS, and HIV treatment in CG.



Primary MN that is considered low risk (eg, modest proteinuria, normal renal function) can be carefully monitored without disease-specific therapy given the potential for spontaneous remission.  However, patients with high-risk disease should be treated with immunosuppressive therapies, such as rituximab monotherapy or corticosteroids combined with cyclophosphamide.  Secondary MN involves treating the underlying cause (eg, immunosuppressive therapy for lupus nephritis, antiviral therapy for hepatitis B, or discontinuation of offending medications); screening for underlying malignancy should be considered in appropriate cases, particularly in patients age >65.

Summary



Nephrotic syndrome, characterized by heavy proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and peripheral edema, results from increased permeability of the glomerular filtration barrier.  The underlying pathophysiology involves noninflammatory injury to the podocytes and glomerular basement membrane, leading to various complications such as hyperlipidemia, hypercoagulability, and increased infection risk.  Nephrotic syndrome can be caused by systemic diseases (eg, diabetes mellitus, amyloidosis, systemic lupus erythematosus) or by renally-limited conditions (eg, minimal change disease, focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, membranous nephropathy).  Diagnosis involves a combination of clinical assessment, serologic tests, and histopathologic examination.  Management includes general therapeutic measures such as RAAS blockade, diuretics, statins, and prophylactic anticoagulation (in select patients), in addition to specific treatment tailored to the underlying etiology.  Podocytopathies (eg, minimal change disease, focal segmental glomerulosclerosis) that are primary are usually treated with corticosteroids or corticosteroid-sparing agents; secondary disease is treated by addressing the underlying cause (eg, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug cessation, weight loss, HIV treatment).  Primary membranous nephropathy treatment depends on disease risk; secondary membranous nephropathy is treated by addressing the underlying cause (eg, offending medication, malignancy).
